historicalName: Calle de le Lezze in Contrada San Moisè, Sestiere di San Marco
englishName: Lezze Alley in the San Moisè Quarter, District of San Marco
historicalDescription: A narrow alleyway in the San Moisè quarter of the San Marco district, near the bustling Piazza San Marco and the Grand Canal. The area was known for its proximity to the heart of Venice's political and religious power.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the nearby Church of San Moisè, this dock would have served visitors to this prominent church in the San Marco district. The church dates back to the 8th century and was an important religious landmark near Calle de le Lezze.

Named after the prominent Lezze family who had their residence along Calle de le Lezze. The Lezze were a noble Venetian family who contributed several important figures to the Republic's government during the Renaissance period.

The San Marco area near Piazza San Marco was known for luxury trades. This dock would have served the jewelry workshops that existed in this affluent area, where artisans crafted pieces for wealthy Venetian nobles and foreign visitors.

The San Marco district housed many artisans who created masks for Venice's famous carnival celebrations. This dock would have been used by these craftsmen to receive materials and ship finished products, particularly significant given the area's proximity to the entertainment districts.

This dock would have served as a secondary customs checkpoint for goods entering the wealthy San Marco district. While the main Dogana was located at the entrance to the Grand Canal, smaller customs stations existed throughout Venice to monitor and tax goods being transported within the city.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the influential Lezze family who resided in this area during the Renaissance period. The Lezze were a noble Venetian family who held several important positions in the Republic's government. This bridge would have been named to honor their presence in the Contrada San Moisè.

Named after the nearby Church of San Moisè, one of the important religious landmarks in this sestiere. The church, dedicated to Moses, was a significant religious site in Renaissance Venice. This bridge would have served as an important connection point for parishioners traveling to the church in the Contrada San Moisè.

connection.historicalName: Ponte dei Orafi di San Marco
connection.englishName: Bridge of the Goldsmiths of Saint Mark
connection.historicalDescription: Named for the goldsmiths and jewelers who likely had workshops in this wealthy area near San Marco. The Sestiere di San Marco was known for luxury trades, and this bridge would have been crossed by craftsmen and wealthy patrons alike. Its proximity to the prestigious San Moisè district made it an important crossing for those dealing in precious metals and gems.

buildingPoints.streetName: Calle dei Oresi di San Moisè
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Goldsmiths of San Moisè
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the goldsmiths who had their workshops in this area near the Church of San Moisè. This part of San Marco was known for luxury artisans who catered to the wealthy nobili of the district.

This street would commemorate the Byzantine merchants who traded in Venice. The San Moisè area was close to Piazza San Marco and the Bacino, making it a logical place for foreign merchants to conduct business.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of the Lezze Family
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the noble Lezze family who had their palazzo in this contrada. Rio Terà indicates this was once a canal that was filled in, a common practice in Venice's urban development history.
A salizada (from 'selciato' meaning paved) was one of the first paved streets in Venice. This area near San Moisè was known for luxury trades including jewelry making for the nobili class.

The Ridotto, Venice's famous gambling house, was established in 1638 near San Moisè. This sottoportego (covered passageway) would have led toward or near this notorious establishment frequented by nobles and wealthy merchants.

buildingPoints.streetName: Calle della Scuola di San Moisè
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the San Moisè Confraternity
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the confraternity or scuola associated with the Church of San Moisè. These religious brotherhoods were important social and charitable institutions in Renaissance Venice.

This fondamenta (street alongside a canal) would reference the bankers who operated in this wealthy area near San Marco. San Moisè was home to many financial professionals due to its proximity to the commercial and political center of the city.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Small Square of the Little Phoenix
buildingPoints.streetDescription: While the famous Teatro La Fenice was built later, this name could refer to a smaller predecessor or to a tavern or shop with this emblem. The campiello (small square) would have been a gathering place in the San Moisè district.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Priuli Court at the Little Lions
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the Priuli family who were prominent Venetian nobles, with several family members serving as Doges. The 'leoncini' (little lions) likely referred to decorative elements or family emblems in the area near San Moisè.

A small branch street (ramo) named after mask makers or mask sellers who would have operated in this area. Venice was famous for its carnival traditions, and San Moisè's proximity to San Marco made it an ideal location for this trade.

Named after a shop sign or noble family emblem in the area. The wealthy San Moisè district near the Grand Canal was home to many luxury shops and prestigious families who might use such symbols in their heraldry.
